segments.text: So, after my leave, my terminal leave, I came out to Seattle for a while.
I went on inactive duty and then back to
Washington, D.C., and I thought we'd try it the first few months with Washington.
I wanted to see how I would like it.
I'd been there many times, but didn't particularly care for the East Coast.
The trout and salmon fishing was not very good in Washington, D.C. and Barnes, so I was concerned about getting back to the West Coast.
And so the next year, in September of 47, I resigned my position with the Civil Service and came to the University of Washington as associate professor in oceanography.
Dr. Thompson had just gotten back from his tour of duty the preceding year at the Chemical Warfare Service because he was also involved.
And we began to try to put the oceanographic group back together again after the war.
and the problem of getting a ship and getting things organized and set up.
And it meant that for the first year, 47 and 48 and 49, I was at Friday Harbor in the summer times, generally teaching a class up there and down here.
in the rest of the year, teaching and looking for a ship and getting things organized for our post-war expansion.
The following year, in 1951, Dr. Thompson felt that he had put in
a long and hard enough duty as...
Pardon me.
So, in 1951, we got together and got Dick Fleming to come out
to head up the new department of oceanography.
So he took over from then a fairly rapidly expanding system.
Did you already have a ship by 51?
At first we hired small ships.
We always had small
a ship to work out in Friday Harbor, either a modified fishing boat.
And then we got the school of fisheries here that built up a small boat.
And so we worked out an agreement with them so that we could use their small boat.
to cruise and work in the Puget Sound waters.
And then we got the Brown Bear, a former Fish and Wildlife Service vessel, to carry on for our work that we could get out into the North Pacific.
And the catalyst
had gone over to private hands and first had gone over into government service and then private hands and it was too small for our purposes.
So we got the Brown Bear.
Did you already have some ideas in mind when you started to outfit this ship?
Did you know about what you thought you wanted on it?
Yes, we knew pretty well what we
what we wanted.
I was a little bit in double duty at those times, because in 1950, 51, and 52, I was working with the icebreakers north of Alaska, from north of Bering Strait to Banks Island.
and up farther north.
In fact, there's my North Pole certificate up there in 1948.
So this meant that I'd have to leave Friday Harbor before the end of the school to take advantage of the good ice conditions.
in August and September, which is the best time of the year to work up in that area.
When you worked with an icebreaker then, exactly what did you do?
Well, we were still working to get an idea of the currents for one thing, the water properties for another, and the
movements of the ice.
And this is, of course, preceding the days when submarines went under the ice.
How long could you usually anticipate being out at a time?
How many days?
Well, I would generally leave on three years.
all sometime in August, early August, and get back about the latter part of September.
And I worked on those cruises a great deal with Waldo Lyons.
who was looking out after the particular interests of the navigation operations in that area.
And I was more or less looking at some of the needed scientific information that we sort of needed to give a better hand on Arctic operations.
So that worked out for about
three years and then I would send up some of my people each year after I stopped going up personally, although I would get an occasional brief.
trip in.
And I think I probably have more North Pole covers than most people.
For philatelists, which I am not, but these are quite a prized set of covers that were stamped with the North Pole.
And so this... And during this time, while we built, starting in about 1950, we built a model of Puget Sound.
And we got Professor Ratray from Caltech up here to do some of our theoretical work in hydrodynamics.
And so on, and he's our present chairman here.
So this was the story up until about the mid-50s.
And I continued going up to Friday Harbor, I guess, the last year was 1957.
But it became quite a rat race to run back and forth when we were trying to operate a ship out of Seattle and teach a class at Friday Harbor in the summertime.
So we continued to expand and grow along through the 60s.
And we got a larger ship, the Thomas T. Thompson, disposed of the Brown Bear that had done us much good in the local open sea, and which we actually got up beyond the
Arctic Circle with it.
How large was it?
It couldn't have been 125 feet.
Or is it 114?
I forget.
Too small to be up at the Arctic Circle.
Well, it's nice in the summertime, but certainly no icebreaker.
That, that, that continued in the 19, about the time we got the Thompson, when Dr. Fleming went over to Turkey for a year and I sort of chaperoned the department for a year in his absence.
And then in 1948,
or 1968, Dr. Rattray relieved Dr. Fleming as chairman of the department, and still is.
And I retired as professor emeritus in 1973.
And I'm still working.
I have several questions I'd like to ask now.
In your first and early work up in the Arctic, was it always simply charting what you thought would be the current flow and ice flow of the Arctic?
You mean in the Arctic beyond the Arctic Circle?
Yeah, right.
Well, and the chemical measurements.
We always took our routine chemical measurements, the more or less customary suite of properties in those days.
We would get dissolved oxygen.
the phosphates, the silicates, and the nitrites.
This was the carryover from my days in 1933 and 1934 up there, although in 1934 I just did get beyond the Arctic Circle.
But the common properties, which are oftentimes very good indicators, aside from the...
the other direct physical measurements you made.

We always make the salinity temperature measurements from which we get the density and the dynamic topography, just like we did on the Grand Banks, which I'd done a little bit when I was working on my doctorate in 1933 and 1934.

We were interested in movements, not only of the ice pack up there, but we were interested in the movements of some of the chunks that broke off the glacier north of Ellesmere Island and was drifting around the Arctic, the T.
ones, T2s, T3s, the ones that Joe Fletcher, Colonel Fletcher, had sort of pioneered on.
And we were interested in the flows there.
We were interested in the, very much interested, of course, in the bathymetry.
And we actually found the Chukchi rice.
out northwest of Barrow and charted it.

And it almost broke my heart when the schedule was such that we couldn't work it out in full detail during the year when we had the ice the farthest north and probably one of the best years ever to work it out.
Why did you decide to come back to the University of Washington?
It was home?
Well, it was home.
It gave me a chance to get out and see.
And then I also, as I say, like to get out with the fly for steelhead and salmon and trout.
it's just a nice place to live.
And then my wife was a native of Seattle, and so there were two minds bent towards the same end of getting back here.
The two other places I liked really best was either Newfoundland or British Columbia.
Well, it's pretty hard to operate Scripps or Woods Hole, either one of those.
It almost seems as if, from hearing your story, that you almost drift into oceanography.
Well, you can see the situation.
Oceanography is made up of
contributing disciplines.

And it was my early feeling that if you had chemistry and physics, you could handle a lot of what went on, whether you were dealing with the environment, whether you're dealing with an engineering problem of a shore.
I was a research engineer at Battelle Memorial Institute, worked on combustion.
and gasification and corrosion and so on.
And then in partnership with some other students, I had my own chemical lab running on spray residues.
And so I think I was fortunate in some ways.
There was never a time in my life that I didn't have two or three jobs that I could have stepped into ahead of me.
I think another phase of it might have been to have gone more into the organic chemical side.
Then you might have ended up as an MD or something like that in some other area.
But if you had a strong base, you
then whatever came up and it suited your fancy why you could sort of turn to it and I did like the sea life going out to sea and the old trips didn't have the modern
communications that we do now where you can send a crew out to join the ship in the Indian Ocean and bring them back in a few weeks.
But there, as I mentioned, my trip in 1933 was five months.
And during the time when I was officially signed at Woods Hole, during that period,
I don't think that I was at Woods Hole more than five, maybe six months in the years from 1940 to 1946.
But the work is very much the same in oceanography, whether you're working in the Atlantic or the Pacific or the Arctic.
For the tropics, you have similar problems.
The same principles apply, but to a different degree.
That's right.
I think you'd be a little colder than one might like it.
Yes.
I noticed the last few years I was in the Arctic why it didn't seem quite as warm as it had in my youth.
How many people usually staffed this ship in terms of oceanographers in the early ships you went on?
Did you have to take...
Two oceanographers?
Three oceanographers?
Well, in a five-month cruise, I was the only oceanographer.
And I had to set up my own stuff on the ship.
And generally, I was assigned ship personnel that I could teach to run some of the routine analysis.
You'd get a pharmacist made or something like that.
But I would put on and take off all the water bottles, read all the thermometers.
Hmm.
And this became a little bit hairy when the stations were coming up at three or four hours of bark.
And I could always catch a few winks between stations in the middle of the night.
But in those days, with some of our materials
The way we ran some of our chemical determinations, the color metric using the old fashioned Nessler tools before the modern optical devices, you found that you had
During the night you would accumulate enough samples that had to be run promptly as soon as it was light enough to see.
So the full daylight hours, even in the northern latitudes, were pretty well saturated with either taking stations or running samples.
And would you just train a member of the crew to help you?
Is that the way you approached it?
That's the way I approached it.
And that was both on the Navy and with the Coast Guard.
And when did you analyze all your data?
Did you do that when you got back?
Had to do that when we got back.
But the point in the field was to ensure that we got the information that we wanted, the quick checks to know that
that the bottles had worked, that we didn't have any leaks or mishaps on it.
And so this was part of the problem.
And this was true, I think, with many of the early oceanographers.
You really had to be a one-man scientist.
One of your contemporaries has complained that what's wrong, he says, with modern oceanography is you don't get your feet wet any longer, meaning not enough oceanographers go to sea.
Do you think it's essential to go to sea to be an oceanographer?
Well, let's put it this way.
There's no one that can really appreciate the problems of the oceans
to their full extent unless he goes out and sees the environment firsthand.
That is, he knows then some of the limitations here.
And it's true that many of the theory and so on can be done ashore.

But given the same capabilities, a person that has experience firsthand what goes on in nature, I think, is better equipped to handle some of the problems than someone that looks at one particular aspect, say, on the theoretical side, for example, without having this experience.
He knows what then can be done to make the field measurements better, what the limitations are, and it makes for a better-rounded scientist.
What would you consider the most amazing innovation, if you had to name just one, which has taken place in oceanography over the last 40 years?
Technically, I mean.
Well, it's hard to separate that which takes place in oceanography from that which takes place in science as a whole, because we must borrow from the different contributing disciplines of science.
A lot of the things that we have borrowed have not been essentially those of themselves
have put us far ahead in new channels in oceanography, but they've enabled us to carry out much more precise measurements on a continuing base that we were otherwise not able to do.
We've seen tremendous developments in means for measuring ocean currents.
tremendous developments in looking at the sea from the air and being able to get an overall view that was not possible in the early days.
We have many new chemical techniques that are higher precision, so always extending
to the lower limits of detection and accuracy and measurements for a number of different compounds and different elements that we could not do in the early days.
And with this ability, then you can make a much more
illuminating analysis.

If you look at what is different now in oceanography than it was in the early days, and if you go through and read the oceans that Svardrop masterminded, you will see that there's very few things in that
framework that have changed in the gross picture.
There's been a lot that has been picked up in the detail.
And we're always going more on that way.
And we have to do so.
So there's a combination of things.
of detecting from a distance, and making measurements from a distance, whether they be from air, or through underwater sound, or what have you.
These have all advanced greatly.
I might tell you a little story, if I might.
Yes, well, meet.
It happened when we were
under radio silence that one of my the ships in which we were conducting some iceberg detection made for measurements by radar on the Grand Banks was situated where we had four bergs and
in the typical dense fog at the Grand Banks, one of the coastal steamers there that had never heard of radar.
It was steaming out of St. John's and going on a certain course.
And it observed the skipper of the ship I had doing the studies.
saw that it was running right into, dead ahead into an iceberg and he didn't want the ship to have a collision and so he opened up on an emergency signal and said unknown ship
going on such and such a course at such and such a speed, you are headed directly for a large iceberg.
Suggest you change course."
And no response, of course.
He got a pretty-
pretty close to this berg.
We opened up again and told him that the berg was now such and such a distance, and he was right on course for it to suggest you change course to such and such.
Well, he still didn't believe it until he saw it.
And he turned around and set another course.
And being in the middle of a square of about four bergs,
why he chose another course that took him towards another iceberg.
And so we let him go along for a while.
And then finally, we opened up and told him he was heading for a second iceberg and suggested that he change course.
And he was still bullheaded, would not change course.
And believe it or not, he tried a third.

And we finally told him when he got close to it, he says, that if you will please change course to such and such a direction and continue for a certain distance, why you will be clear of all birds and can proceed.
And he did.
But I've often wondered what that fellow...
Thought you had eyes?
